57. Here too was Paris, who had begun
to carve Oenone in the bark of an elm tree
with a scythe, but was assailed
by three Goddesses and had not been able
to finish completely, but left it thus
in order to offer judgment and prevent conflict
among these three, all standing waiting, naked before him,
who was the most beautiful and worthy of the prize.
right-middleHere is the main point of the History, that is, the Judgment of Paris.

58. But what was especially to be observed and respected
as very ingenious, beautiful, and unusual,
was the great attentiveness and unfettered talent
of this judicious painter, through which
there stood, created by him,
Juno and Minerva, both outstandingly lovely,
so completely perfect, that he
could not have done better.

59. Now since he did now know how to make Venus
more beautiful than the other two, which is fitting,
and as these two stood facing forward.
he made the most of this and cleverly painted Venus
with her back turned. Thus the astute Artist
excused himself for delighting with deceit,
suggesting that, if she turned around,
she would surpass the others in beauty.

right-middleNote here a fine conceit copied from the life of Timanthes: to make observers believe that Venus, if seen from the front, would be the fairest; just as Agamemnon, with head covered, would be deemed the saddest.

60. Many more things, diverse in nature,
were painted here, according to the Poet’s verses.
So these people went to perform their Sacrifice
before the image of Pales, engaging in
much Ceremony, in that building.
But these Examples show us
how to compose with abundance and intelligence,
and thereby happily to Poeticize.

61. Who, awakened by this, shall not now discover
their wit in Composition by following in the footsteps
of Comedies, where crazy buffoons
or other characters perform
solely to delight the audience:
for [compositions] with so few elements are useless,
performed, they have no perfect
nature, but only additions or supplements.

62. Thus one should elaborate a simple History,
like our example of the Poet’s text;
right-middleSannasarus was a Neapolitan Nobleman who was able to write about painting: how to make additions in a Poetic manner.
